thread.title: North East news LIVE: Latest breaking news, sport, weather, traffic and travel

author: Kathryn Riddell
title: North East news LIVE: Latest breaking news, sport, weather, traffic and travel
text:
It will be low tides at these times tonight. 
Sunderland: 10.55am 
River Tyne (North Shields): 10.59am 
Newcastle: 11.07am KEY EVENT Opencast mine rejection to be challenged 
Banks Mining intends to challenge the Secretary of State Sajid Javid’s decision to reject its Highthorn surface mine planning application. 
The firm gained unanimous approval for the Highthorn planning application from Northumberland County Council’s planning committee in July 2016, only for the decision to subsequently be called in for review by the then Department for Communities and Local Government, which then led to a public inquiry into the project taking place last year. The proposed site of the Highthorn opencast mine (Image: Supplied pic. Free to use.) 
Last month, Mr Javid chose to disregard the recommendation of the planning inspector that the Highthorn scheme should be allowed to go ahead. 
But now, Banks Mining has notified Mr Javid of its intention to lodge a challenge with the High Court against his decision on the grounds. 10:23 Kathryn Riddell Metro works this weekend 
A replacement bus service will be running between Pelaw and South Hylton on Sunday morning because of engineering works. 
Metros will be back on after 11.30am. 10:13 Kathryn Riddell See stunning sunrise at Whitley Bay 
With a forecast of sunny and hot weather later today, there were high hopes when the sun came up this morning. 
PA photographer Owen Humphreys captured the red skies first thing at the Whitley Bay coast. (Image: Owen Humphreys/PA) KEY EVENT De La Rue will NOT appeal blue passport move 
De La Rue has revealed that it will not appeal the decision by the UK Government to hand a contract to print the iconic blue British passports to a French rival. De La Rue in Gateshead, which has lost the contract to make British passports (Image: Daily Mirror) 
De La Rue has printed UK passports from its Team Valley factory, in Gateshead , for the last 10 years but last month the Government contract was issued to Franco-Dutch firm Gemalto. 
The decision caused widespread controversy as the contract will involve EU-headquartered Gemalto printing the first batch of blue passports after Brexit . It could also put around 100 Gateshead jobs at risk.
